message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including tearing and burning quality pain radiating to the back, suggest a possible esophageal rupture or perforation due to the presence of a large hiatal hernia. Contrast esophagography with gastrografin is often performed to confirm the diagnosis. Coronary angiography and contrast-enhanced CT of the aorta are not indicated based on the patient's symptoms and history. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy was performed the day before and diagnosed gastritis, which is not relevant to the patient's current symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with acute upper abdominal pain, which may suggest a perforation of the hiatal hernia. The mediastinal lucency on chest x-ray may suggest a diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome, which is characterized by a perforation of the esophagus due to vomiting or retching. Thus, the most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be a contrast esophagography with gastrografin to evaluate for esophageal perforation. Coronary angiography would not be indicated in this case, as the patient's troponin I level is only mildly elevated and his EKG findings are more consistent with a left bundle branch block than acute coronary syndrome. Contrast-enhanced CT of the aorta would not be indicated in this case, as the patient's symptoms and examination findings are not consistent with aortic dissection. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy may be diagnostic, but is not appropriate in the acute setting when esophageal perforation is suspected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest a possible aortic dissection, and the physical exam shows crackling with every heartbeat, which further supports this. A contrast esophagography with gastrografin can help diagnose a hiatal hernia and rule out an aortic dissection involving the esophagus. Coronary angiography is not necessary at this point since the EKG does not show acute ischemia. A CT of the aorta can be helpful for diagnosing an aortic dissection, but it does not directly assess the hiatal hernia. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is not needed as it was performed recently and has already shown gastritis and hiatal hernia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a potential aortic dissection, which is confirmed by the mediastinal lucency on the chest x-ray. A contrast esophagography with gastrografin can help diagnose the presence and severity of a hiatal hernia, which may or may not be contributing to the patient's symptoms. Coronary angiography and esophagogastroduodenoscopy are unlikely to be helpful in this situation, and a contrast-enhanced CT of the aorta would confirm the diagnosis of aortic dissection but is not the most appropriate next step as immediate intervention is needed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an aortic dissection, and the CT scan is the best test to diagnose it. However, since the patient is in distress, he cannot be safely transferred to the CT scan, and a contrast esophagography with gastrografin can help diagnose the hiatal hernia and potentially rule out other causes of upper abdominal pain. Coronary angiography is not indicated as the patient’s troponin I level is not elevated, and there are no significant EKG changes to suggest an acute myocardial infarction. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy was performed recently and is unlikely to be the root of the current issue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of tearing and burning quality pain that radiates to the back, along with a history of a large hiatal hernia. This suggests a possible esophageal rupture or perforation, and the most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be contrast esophagography with gastrografin. This will allow visualization of any leaks or perforations in the esophagus, confirming or ruling out this potential complication. Coronary angiography would be unlikely to be helpful in this scenario, as the patient's symptoms do not suggest acute coronary syndrome. Contrast-enhanced CT of the aorta may be useful to rule out aortic dissection, given the patient's family history and hypertension, but it is not the most appropriate next step in this scenario. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy was already performed and diagnosed gastritis and a large hiatal hernia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of tearing and burning pain that radiates to the back, along with a history of smoking and the family history of aortic dissection, suggest the possibility of aortic dissection. The chest x-ray showing mediastinal lucency and the elevated troponin level further support this possibility. Contrast esophagography with gastrografin can help confirm the diagnosis of aortic dissection and determine if there is a hiatal hernia present. Coronary angiography is not indicated as there is no evidence of myocardial infarction. Contrast-enhanced CT of the aorta is an option, but contrast esophagography with gastrografin is less invasive and can provide similar diagnostic information. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is not likely to be helpful in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible aortic dissection, which can be confirmed or ruled out by a contrast esophagography with gastrografin. This test is used to visualize the aorta and determine if there is an aortic dissection. Coronary angiography is not indicated at this point as the patient’s troponin is only slightly elevated and his ECG is consistent with his known left bundle branch block. Contrast-enhanced CT of the aorta may also be used to detect aortic dissection, but contrast esophagography with gastrografin may be preferred because it does not expose the patient to ionizing radiation. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is not indicated given the patient’s symptoms and history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and medical history suggest an aortic dissection. The chest x-ray confirms a large hiatal hernia and mediastinal lucency, which is characteristic of an aortic dissection. A contrast esophagography with gastrografin can help confirm the diagnosis by showing the presence and extent of the dissection. Coronary angiography and esophagogastroduodenoscopy are not likely to be useful in diagnosing an aortic dissection. Contrast-enhanced CT of the aorta is an option, but contrast esophagography with gastrografin is less invasive and can provide similar information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible aortic dissection, which can be visualized using a contrast esophagography with gastrografin. Coronary angiography may be considered if there is suspicion of myocardial infarction, but the patient's troponin levels are not significantly elevated. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy was already performed and showed no acute pathology. Contrast-enhanced CT of the aorta is also an option but contrast esophagography is less invasive and a quicker diagnostic test.
